{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3487348,"name":"Wihy","username":"Wihy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wihy/{size}/225659_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-19T06:40:35.279Z","cooked":"

Let’s say I wanted to automatically align the robot with the closest reef branch, using pathplanner’s pathfinding.

I have taken the following approach.

Create 6 triggers, one for each side of the reef, dictating whether this is the side the robot is the closest to.
Then, for each trigger, do the following
button.and(trigger).whileTrue(AutoBuilder.pathfindToPose(specific side of the reef here))

Another way I thought of doing it is creating a command class, and doing the checks on onExecute. The problem with this is that I wouldn’t be able to use AutoBuilder.pathfindToPose, as this method returns a command.

But the first strategy is not ideal, and involves the repetition of lots of code.
What would be the most concise and scalable way of doing this? (preferably using PP’s pathfinding command)

I originally tried to do auto align like this, but I found that it is a lot easier, faster, and more effective to just do 3 PID controllers, one for x, y, and theta, and then to just feed their output into your drive function.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-19T06:46:16.652Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":145.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482630,"topic_slug":"reef-alignment-in-code","display_username":"Jackson Elia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53032,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4829 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/reef-alignment-in-code/482630/2","custom_user_title":"4829 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3487359,"name":"sam liu","username":"catrix","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-19T07:17:35.768Z","cooked":"
Wihy:

Another way I thought of doing it is creating a command class, and doing the checks on onExecute. The problem with this is that I wouldn’t be able to use AutoBuilder.pathfindToPose, as this method returns a command.

You can use Commands.defer() to create the command on schedule.

Like:

/** 
* decides which reef to align and return the desired robot pose for auto alignment
**/
public Pose2d decideAutoAlignmentTarget() {
    return ...;
}

button.whileTrue(Commands.defer(() -> AutoABuilder.pathfindToPose(
        decideAutoAlignmentTarget(),
        constrains,
        0)));

Or, you can use Selecting-Compositions to allow your command to be decisive.

Thank you!

Wihy:

The problem with this is that I wouldn’t be able to use AutoBuilder.pathfindToPose, as this method returns a command.

Is there a way to run the pathfinding without returning the actual command?

For example, in the CTRE Swerve API, instead of returning the swerve commands, you can use SetControl() to run it directly

Not with PathPlanner, no. The best bet is to defer a pathfollowing command.
